results.title: Me, myself, I
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional, Fabien Liron and Pip Karmel
results.brief_description: Pamela is a successful writer working for a magazine, single, independent, professional, well dressed, but hapless, lonely, depressed, confused about where her road has led her, reading self-help books in search of an answer. On her birthday, demoralised after an awful blind date and considering suicide as her next career move, Pamela contemplates how her life would have turned out if she had married Robert, her early 20s sweetheart. Pamela gets the chance to find out when she meets her doppelganger and they swap roles. Pamela spends a few weeks in a house in the leafy suburbs, with Robert and their three children. Over that time Pamela discovers that it is not all plain sailing trying to balance work commitments, child rearing and a dormant sex-life. A switcheroo comedy, Rachel Griffiths takes the title role/s and plays Pamela as a woman searching for identity, sexual satisfaction and personal gratification from life, whatever role she chooses. “Me, myself, I” is a female empowerment film in that it recognises the burden of housework, the compromises of relationships, the need for sexual satisfaction and the demands of children from a woman’s perspective, comically exploring these issues without (for the most part) reducing the characters to displays of sentimental mawkishness. Cast also includes David Roberts, Sandy Winton, Yael Stone, Shaun Loseby.

results.title: Me depressed?: don't make me laugh
results.creator_credit: Monkey See Productions, Nick Torrens and Christine Mason
results.brief_description: Beneath Spike Milligan’s comedic career lay a severe and debilitating depression, and he is the perfect candidate to present this helpful video on depression and ways of treating it. He speaks with sufferers as well as experts, providing a useful tool for sufferers, family and friends, and health professionals. Included on this tape are; types of depression, the importance of daily activity, charting the rise and fall of moods, controlling negative thoughts, the role of medication, the role of family and friends, suicide, and where to go for help.

results.title: Me at the Zoo
results.brief_description: Me at the zoo is the first video that was uploaded to YouTube. It was uploaded on April 23, 2005 at 20:27:12 PDT by the site’s co-founder Jawed Karim, with the username “jawed” and recorded by his high school friend Yakov Lapitsky. He created a YouTube account on the same day. - Wikipedia

constellations_other.name: Home movies, fiction and reality blurred
constellations_other.description: The accessibility and portability of cameras has had a big impact on how we see ourselves and the world. As camera technology continues to evolve, so do our ways of seeing, with the line between reality and fiction disappearing.

results.title: Me and you kangaroo
results.creator_credit: Bert Salzman Productions, Learning Corporation of America and Bert Salzman
results.brief_description: Presents a story about the love of a young Australian boy for the baby kangaroo which he raises after its mother has been accidentally killed by a car.

results.title: Me and the monsters
results.creator_credit: Billy Budd Films, Alcohol and Drug Foundation and Bill Cleary
results.brief_description: Once upon a time there was a boy who had trouble - and his trouble was monsters. And whenever he had trouble, he saw monsters. A vieled animated instructional film for children advocating piece-of-mind, safety, antidrugs and racial harmony. Song written and perfomrd by Bill Cleary.

results.title: Me and the Girls (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, Alan Smallcross and Jack Gold
results.brief_description: George Banks is dying and from his hospital bed he reflects on his colourful, unconventional and at times poignant years as the leader of a travelling troupe of dancing girls. He remembers the good and bad times, his friends and loved ones, especially his one great love, Harry. Set in Switzerland in 1938, this drama is based on the play by Noel Coward. Stars Tom Courtenay as George Banks. Rated: PG.

results.title: Me and my world
results.brief_description: Annie, with the help of her alien friend Cosmo, learns that all things in the universe fit into one of three categories - animal, mineral or vegetable. For her science project she must explain an example of one thing which fits into all three categories, and through investigating the world around them Annie and Cosmo discover water is such an element - it can exist in three states - solid, liquid and gas. Through examining water, Annie develops a greater appreciation for the value of water to all life on earth. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.

results.title: Me and my friends
results.creator_credit: Coastline Community College, Southern California Consortium and Harry Ratner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “Time to grow”.
This program discusses the importance of friendship during middle childhood, a time when the world becomes increasingly real and competitive.
